headline: Leona Maguire: ‘I was in China and Pádraig rang me from Arizona to give me his opinion on things’ – The Irish Times
context: Leona Maguire still has that pioneering spirit, a hunger and belief that the best has yet to come: in a trailblazing career that so far has seen the 30-year-old Cavan player become the first Irish woman to win on the LPGA Tour and the Ladies European Tour and play Solheim Cup, there remain boxes to be ticked, targets to achieve.

annotations.paragraph: On a week’s break from the LPGA Tour ahead of another busy summer campaign that includes four Major championships on her itinerary, Maguire could be found yesterday at a sun-kissed Grange Golf Club in Dublin’s leafy southside suburb of Rathfarnham. “I brought the sun back,” she quipped, her time spent conducting a clinic for those attending the Davy corporate day while also perching herself on the tee box of the course’s second hole.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about Maguire's current activities and her engagement with the public, which is relevant to understanding her current state and preparation.

annotations.paragraph: Maguire’s season is already nine tournaments long but there is a sense that it is really only getting going, as if she has tiptoed on her campaign so far and – having spent much of the winter’s off-season fine-tuning her swing – is ready to shift up the gears.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers insight into Maguire's current season and her preparation, which is relevant to her career progression.

annotations.paragraph: “I’ve had a steady start to the year I suppose,” said Maguire, who has not missed a cut. “I’d a lot of tidying up to do over the off-season and had to fine tune a few things. I’m driving the ball a lot better than I was last year, so that was the main priority, to get that sorted. Maybe I’m not as high up the leaderboard yet as I would like but I’ve been very consistent. I am seeing some nice progress.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes a direct quote from Maguire about her performance and improvements, which is relevant to her career and current form.

annotations.paragraph: Maguire – who has a new caddie by her side, Shane O’Connell, who previously worked with John Murphy on the DP World Tour – returns to the LPGA Tour for next week’s Mizuho Americas Open at Liberty National in New Jersey and then has another week’s break before the Mexico Open at Mayakaba and onwards to the US Women’s Open at Erin Hills in Wisconsin.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about Maguire's upcoming schedule and her new caddie, which is pertinent to her career developments.

annotations.paragraph: That US Open will be the second Major of the LPGA Tour season (she finished tied-67th in last week’s Chevron) with the KPMG US Women’s PGA at Frisco, the Evian Championship in France and the AIG Women’s Open at Royal Porthcawl all pencilled into Maguire’s diary as she bids to add a Major title to her impressive career curriculum vitae.
annotations.reason: Provides specific details about Maguire's upcoming schedule and her goals.

annotations.paragraph: Of those Major ambitions, Maguire said: “They are obviously big events, they are big golf courses, they are the strongest fields of the year but they are also similar fields to what we play week-in, week-out now on the LPGA Tour. It is such a global tour the major fields don’t actually differ very much to any other week. It is a lot of the same faces you are trying to beat week-in and week-out and it is a case of putting yourself in contention as many times as possible.
annotations.reason: Includes Maguire's perspective on the challenges of major tournaments.

annotations.paragraph: “You see that with Rory [McIlroy], how long it took him to get over the line since his last Major, it is not easy. They are Majors for a reason and you just have to keep knocking on the door and keep putting yourself in that spot and be ready when you have the chance.”
annotations.reason: Provides insight into Maguire's mindset and comparison to another golfer.

annotations.paragraph: Maguire’s referencing to McIlroy – who completed the career Grand Slam with his Masters win at Augusta last month while also ending a more than 10 years drought since his last Major title back in 2014, the US PGA – is a worthy point.

annotations.reason: Shares Maguire's personal reaction and its impact, adding depth to her narrative.

annotations.paragraph: Maguire’s consistency so far this season has yet to see her get into contention in a tournament but, playing the game of patience, the next few weeks and months – on a tour where the strength in depth is greater than ever – will bring one big event after another, with the KPMG Irish Open at Carton House slotted nicely into her schedule the week ahead of the Evian. It is one of a five-week stretch of events that takes in the Meijer Classic, the KPMG Women’s PGA, the Dow Championship, the Irish Open and the Evian.

May be that is something in 30, 40 50 years I look back on hopefully.

annotations.paragraph: “I might have been the first to do a lot on the women’s side but the lads have been very good to me, Pádraig Harrington has been very generous with his time, as has Paul McGinley, it has been nice to have them to lean on and to ask questions.
annotations.reason: The paragraph highlights the support Maguire has received from prominent male golfers, adding context to her career.

annotations.paragraph: “Even when I was looking for a new caddie a few weeks ago both Paul and Paddy were straight back to me when I asked for advice.
